label: American Samoa
result:
In American Samoa, there are no restrictions on eligibility to vote based on criminal convictions. Register to vote with our friends at Vote.org.

For more information about voting in Maine, visit the Secretary of State's website.

questions.value: Have you ever been charged or convicted of a felony?

options.result:
In Arkansas, no one is disenfranchised for misdemeanors or any convictions other than felonies. You are still eligible to vote.

Register to vote with our friends at Vote.org.

questions.value: Are you currently incarcerated, on probation, or parole for a felony of moral turpitude?

options.result:
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Individuals who have been convicted of felonies of moral turputide are eligible to vote only upon completion of their sentence, including probation and parole.

Common felonies of moral turpitude include: murder, manslaughter, assault, sexual assault, sexual abuse of a minor, robery, arson, burglary, theft, forgery, endangering the welfare of a minor, riot, criminal mischef, misconduct involving a controlled substance, and distribution or possession of child pornography.

NOTE: This is not a complete list of felonies of moral turpitude. If you are unsure if your conviction qualifies as a felony of moral turpitude, call or have a friend or family member call 1-866-OUR-VOTE for assistance.

In Arkansas, no one is disenfranchised for misdemeanors or any convictions other than felonies. You are still eligible to vote.

Register to vote with our friends at Vote.org.

questions.value: Have you ever been charged or convicted of a felony or misdemeanor?

options.result:
In Colorado, no one is disenfranchised for misdemeanors or any convictions other than felonies. If you are incarcerated but have not been convicted of a felony, you are still eligible to vote. That’s true even if you have been charged with a felony.

Register to vote with our friends at Vote.org.

questions.value: Are you currently incarcerated for a felony or misdemeanor?

options.result: In Colorado, no one is disenfranchised for misdemeanors or any convictions other than felonies. If you are incarcerated but have not been convicted of a felony, you are still eligible to vote. Please request absentee ballot from office administrators at your complex.
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Your right to vote will be restored when you are released from incarceration, even if you are still on probation or parole.

In Colorado, no one is disenfranchised for misdemeanors or any convictions other than felonies. If you are incarcerated but have not been convicted of a felony, you are still eligible to vote. That’s true even if you have been charged with a felony.

Register to vote with our friends at Vote.org.
